elements.subject: Object Storage for CMS in the HL-LHC era (R&D Initiative)

description.raw:
Demonstrate feasability of using Ceph object store technology to store and retrieve CMS event data products at a finer granularity than file-level. Benchmark storage usage and analysis access performance and compare to traditional file-level storage solutions.

R&D Postdoc: [**Nick Smith**](https://uscms-software-and-computing.github.io/postdocs/nsmith-.html)

Demonstrate feasability of using Ceph object store technology to store and retrieve CMS event data products at a finer granularity than file-level. Benchmark storage usage and analysis access performance and compare to traditional file-level storage solutions.

R&D Postdoc: Nick Smith

Test NTuple extraction from object store using ServiceX or similar technology.

elements.subject: Improve the resiliency/reliability of the  Workflow Management System to decrease processing tails Q3 2023

description.raw: A major challenge facing the WM system is the timely completion of workflows (WFs) because of long tails in WF completion time. Failures that require human effort from which to recover comprise a major source of long workflow tails. These failures can be addressed through**reliability** (having a smaller failure rate) or**resiliency** (the ability to recover automatically in the face of failures).
description.html: A major challenge facing the WM system is the timely completion of workflows (WFs) because of long tails in WF completion time. Failures that require human effort from which to recover comprise a major source of long workflow tails. These failures can be addressed throughreliability (having a smaller failure rate) orresiliency (the ability to recover automatically in the face of failures).

ancestors.title: GC3: Transforming Scientific Data Analysis Process
WP 3.3 Analysis Software

parent.title: WP 3.3 Analysis Software

description.raw:
The four USCMS AFs have organically adopted column-wise data structures (awkward arrays, RDataFrames) and tools suitable to their analysis (i.e. COFFEA). These data structures not only help optimize throughput, having a direct impact on WP 3.2, but also facilitate the adoption of a more declarative analysis style and of notebook-style data analysis environments like Jupyter Lab etc. The work that the four USCMS AFs did within the community, taking part in educational events like the LPC data analysis schools and already providing support to external users, helped widen the adoption of these novel approaches within CMS. As mentioned in WP 3.1, the AGC benchmarks have been developed around the usage of column-wise data structures.

While this part of the full AF software infrastructure seems to be established, work towards the further development and long-term maintenance of software packages that support columnar analysis is a goal of this work package.

elements.subject: Improve the resiliency/reliability of the  Workflow Management System to decrease processing tails Q4 2023

description.raw: A major challenge facing the WM system is the timely completion of workflows (WFs) because of long tails in WF completion time. Failures that require human effort from which to recover comprise a major source of long workflow tails. These failures can be addressed through**reliability** (having a smaller failure rate) or**resiliency** (the ability to recover automatically in the face of failures).
description.html: A major challenge facing the WM system is the timely completion of workflows (WFs) because of long tails in WF completion time. Failures that require human effort from which to recover comprise a major source of long workflow tails. These failures can be addressed throughreliability (having a smaller failure rate) orresiliency (the ability to recover automatically in the face of failures).

description.raw:
## Current Responsibilities for U.S. CMS

U.S. CMS, together with OSG, is largely responsible for running the CMS job submission infrastructure, and for supporting the job submission and workflow management systems. U.S. CMS is leading the relevant software development efforts, collaborating with the HTCondor team and other partners (glideinWMS and WM Agent), and with the HEPCloud team at Fermilab for access to HPC sites.

## Gap Analysis, R&D Goals

Our processing needs are growing faster than a flat budget scenario allows, and therefore provisioning our own tier-based computing system to keep pace with needs may be cost-prohibitive. It will become necessary to efficiently use a more diverse portfolio of data processing facilities, including traditional US T1/T2 sites, cost-effective cloud resources, and HPC centers, will be necessary. Workflow systems and edge services also must evolve to effectively orchestrate usage of heterogeneous hardware such as GPU coprocessors.

## Metric of Success

The ability for U.S. CMS to use the most effective mixture of self-managed, HPC, and Cloud computing resources, of both traditional x86 and GPU coprocessor type, to fulfill its obligations to the CMS experiment, with high availability and high utilization efficiency.

elements.subject: WP 2.2: Develop exascale storage & dataflow solutions

description.raw:
## Current Responsibilities for U.S. CMS

U.S. CMS current provides 20% of the archival tape storage for the CMS experiment raw data (40% of non-CERN resources) and 30% of disk storage for data processing and analysis tasks. U.S. CMS sites provisions storage above-pledge to support improved analysis throughput.

## Gap Analysis, R&D Goals

The projected archival storage needs exceed a flat budget scenario, and the tape drive requirements to deliver data in a timely manner to reprocessing campaigns are significant. Dedicated R&D towards high-throughput data delivery to processing systems for exabyte-scale datasets is necessary.

A data lake system that can optimize cost vs. quality of service (tape/disk/flash) at the granularity of physics analysis (sub-file) may ease the burden for commissioning the new detectors in the early years of HL-LHC and reduce overall disk storage requirements in the long-term.

RNTuple has provisions for storing the sub-file data columns corresponding to a range of eventsnamely, pagesin binary objects separate from the file. A metadata system would then manage these page objects and assemble on-request an RNTuple file that contains references to the subset of pages needed for a particular analysis task, where the page data is stored in an S3 service. In this service, splitting and joining the object data columns from multiple data tiers becomes a fast metadata operation, and infrequently-accessed data columns could be offloaded to tape storage.

## Metric of Success

Exabyte-scale archival and disk storage systems serving: processing jobs at HPC, cloud, and self-managed resources; and data origins for analysis facilities, possibly accessed through ServiceX or other data transformation services. Need to demonstrate:

*   Ability to operate a federated infrastructure that acts as a single storage service split across multiple sites via a hub-and-spoke cache model
*   Capability for bulk transfer in and out of the lake as well as internal re-balancing
*   Ability to track usage of individual data columns by applications and offload unused data columns from high-cost storage
description.html:
Current Responsibilities for U.S. CMS

U.S. CMS current provides 20% of the archival tape storage for the CMS experiment raw data (40% of non-CERN resources) and 30% of disk storage for data processing and analysis tasks. U.S. CMS sites provisions storage above-pledge to support improved analysis throughput.

Gap Analysis, R&D Goals

The projected archival storage needs exceed a flat budget scenario, and the tape drive requirements to deliver data in a timely manner to reprocessing campaigns are significant. Dedicated R&D towards high-throughput data delivery to processing systems for exabyte-scale datasets is necessary.

A data lake system that can optimize cost vs. quality of service (tape/disk/flash) at the granularity of physics analysis (sub-file) may ease the burden for commissioning the new detectors in the early years of HL-LHC and reduce overall disk storage requirements in the long-term.

RNTuple has provisions for storing the sub-file data columns corresponding to a range of eventsnamely, pagesin binary objects separate from the file. A metadata system would then manage these page objects and assemble on-request an RNTuple file that contains references to the subset of pages needed for a particular analysis task, where the page data is stored in an S3 service. In this service, splitting and joining the object data columns from multiple data tiers becomes a fast metadata operation, and infrequently-accessed data columns could be offloaded to tape storage.

Metric of Success

Exabyte-scale archival and disk storage systems serving: processing jobs at HPC, cloud, and self-managed resources; and data origins for analysis facilities, possibly accessed through ServiceX or other data transformation services. Need to demonstrate:

  • Ability to operate a federated infrastructure that acts as a single storage service split across multiple sites via a hub-and-spoke cache model
  • Capability for bulk transfer in and out of the lake as well as internal re-balancing
  • Ability to track usage of individual data columns by applications and offload unused data columns from high-cost storage

elements.subject: WP 2.3: Develop a content delivery network for petascale analysis

description.raw:
## Current Responsibilities for U.S. CMS

U.S. CMS, through the Fermilab LPC analysis facility and emerging analysis facilities sited at universities, provides resources for quasi-interactive data analysis. These facilities must be provided with input data within reasonable geographic distance (round-trip latency), necessitating an integrated network and cache system.

## Gap Analysis, R&D Goals

R&D towards lake-edge data transformation tools and caching solutions to ensure analysts continue to be able to access Any data, Any time, Anywhere (AAA evolution). Networking R&D to ensure reliable streaming of data from the lake to data processing facilities.

## Metric of Success

User analysis in HL-LHC is at least as performant and reliable as it is in Run 3.

description.raw:
## Current Responsibilities for U.S. CMS

U.S. CMS, in partnership with Fermilab, provides core expertise, development, and maintenance efforts for the CMS software framework. The CMSSW framework fully supports multi-threading, multi-processing, and scheduling framework modules for specific functions (like track fitting or cluster finding) to run on co-processors. This way, use of heterogeneous CPU architectures, including GPUs, FPGAs, and even remote execution on dedicated AI/ML inference engines etc. are supported. Recent HL-LHC targeted R&D has successfully enabled the use of GPUs as CPU accelerators, in order to effectively use the next generation of HPC.

## Gap Analysis, R&D Goals

The CMSSW framework is now able to support portable code that can run on CPUs as well as GPUs. The CMS collaboration has adopted Alpaka as the portability library for Run 3. Future R\\&D will be needed to adapt CMSSW for more efficient Input/Output data formats. In particular development will be needed to make CMSSW compatible with the RNTuple data format developed by the ROOT team.

## Metric of Success

Number of CMS data tiers capable of being read and written in RNtuple format.

ancestors.title: GC1: Modernizing Physics Software and improving algorithms

parent.title: GC1: Modernizing Physics Software and improving algorithms

description.raw:
## Current Responsibilities for U.S. CMS

U.S. CMS has significant responsibilities for upgrading detector components for the HL-LHC that provide significant challenges in terms of algorithmic performance for simulation and reconstruction software. U.S. CMS is expected to contribute its share towards CMS software, with a focus on these detector components that the U.S. has built or plans to upgrade. U.S. CMS and Fermilab provide concomitant software development support to the upgrade efforts, to assess and achieve required HL-LHC software performance levels, and to be ready to in future provide life-cycle support for U.S. CMS upgrade deliverables. U.S. CMS has also long been responsible for oversight of the overall CMS Reconstruction software. This includes development planning, code management, and performance benchmarking. U.S. CMS has expertise and leadership in tracking software development and maintenance, and has significant responsibilities for upgrading the CMS tracking detector systems for the HL-LHC (Outer Tracker, DOE supported and Inner Tracker, NSF supported). The mkFit and LST projects targeting both Run 3 and HL-LHC are led by U.S. CMS, in collaboration with IRIS-HEP, that improve tracking algorithms by making use of of accelerators. U.S. CMS also supports the development of Particle Flow and Vertex reconstruction.

## Gap Analysis, R&D Goals

Charged particle tracking and vertex reconstruction are particularly challenging and pose performance risks. Up-front software engineering support for detector upgrades that have significant DOE investments helps ensure these detectors will be fully effective, and that long-term software and algorithm support can be provided at manageable cost. These efforts fill a gap in the current CMS algorithm development space as the bulk of the CMS code remains in legacy format. In order to achieve dramatic decreases in processing time, it's likely that a majority of the code base needs to be capable of being executed on accelerators. Prototype versions of Tracking, Vertex, and Particle Flow reconstruction adapted for portability libraries have been developed. The ongoing R\\&D goals are to improve their computing and physics performance and to adapt more of the reconstruction code.

## Metric of Success

Computing performance in terms of throughput of individual reconstruction and simulation algorithms. Physics performance in terms of efficiency, misidentification rate, and resolution for individual objects formed by these algorithms.

elements.subject: WP 1.3 Explore the Capabilites of AI/ML

description.raw:
## Current Responsibilities for U.S. CMS

The prevalence and performance of AI/ML tools has grown drastically in recent years. These techniques may provide an alternate approach to particle reconstruction or detector simlation. Furthermore, HPC centers and cloud facilities are likely to consist of hardware optimized for AI/ML workflows. It is paramount that U.S. CMS explore these techniques and study their full capabilities. The HGCal that will replace the existing CMS endcap calorimetry for HL-LHC offers a particularly well-suited test bed for advanced AI/ML algorithms, and U.S. CMS is a major contributor to this detector project.

## Gap Analysis, R&D Goals

Offline reconstruction for the HGCal is expected to require significant processing needs for the HL-LHC. Pattern recognition down to low transverse energies to make full use of the HGCal physics potential will be a major challenge, with overlapping patterns due to high particle density in the forward direction, and due to high granularity detector segmentation. Computing demands are increased by orders of magnitude with respect to the current calorimeter, to be reigned in by advanced algorithms. Current R\\&D effort includes looking into the use of Graph Neural Networks for the event reconstruction and into using AI denoising techniques for the simulation of the HGCal detector response. While AI/ML tools look promising the processing needs for inference of large networks is still expected to be significant. Optimization of this inference time is part of further R\\&D in WP 1.4 and GC2.

## Metric of Success

This work package is to explore modern AI/ML paradigms and apply them to CMS software and quantify their physics and computing performance.

description.raw:
## Current Responsibilities for U.S. CMS

As described in the above work packages, U.S. CMS is a leader in the development of several algorithms that are compatible with hardware accelerators, namely GPUs. U.S. CMS and Fermilab have also developed the CMS infrastructure software to make use of opportunistic resources, e.g. at HPC centers. As described in WP2, U.S. CMS and Fermilab are behind the development of the SONIC framework that can be used offload GPU algorithms to execute on remote resources.

## Gap Analysis, R&D Goals

The goals of this work package are to combine the individual heterogeneous algorithms into complete simulation workflows. These workflows must be able to efficiently execute on a wide variety of computing resources and environments. The SONIC package is a potential solution to these challenges as it allows for a more flexible and dynamic allocation of resources, both local and remote. Current R\\&D efforts involve adapting the LST tracking algorithm to be compatible with SONIC and implementing cutting-edge AI/ML frameworks that are being used in Run 3 MINIAOD production workflows into SONIC. A thorough study of both the physics and computing performance of these workflows on different signal and background processes using the CMS production system is desirable.

## Metric of Success

Computing performance in terms of throughput of complete simulation workflows. Physics performance in terms of efficiency, misidentification rate, and resolution for complex objects relying on multiple algorithms.

elements.subject: WP 3.1 Prototyping a HL-LHC Data Analysis Facility

description.raw:
## Current Responsibilities for U.S. CMS

The U.S. CMS S&C Operations Program is responsible for providing excellent data analysis support and facilities to the whole U.S. CMS community. It makes computational and data infrastructure available for job submission and data access, at all Tier-2 centers, and at Fermilab with the LPC-CAF analysis facility. With about 150 active analysis users per month, U.S. researchers comprise a large fraction of the total CMS analysis activities. For HL-LHC we expect the need for specialized Data Analysis Facilities that will provide high-throughput and fast-turnaround data analysis services, as outlined in the Community White Paper \[6\].

## Gap Analysis, R&D Goals

The CWP provides a detailed gap analysis. The R&D goals in this area include providing a prototype version of an analysis facility that can support HL-LHC-level throughput and services. Service goals include the ability to authenticate users without X.509, efficiently access CMS data from the facility, non-terminal-based (i.e. notebooks) interface to the facility, interactive scale-out capabilities (such as Dask), and beyond-batch capabilities.

This work package will utilize four R&D efforts: the Elastic Analysis Facility (EAF) at Fermilab, the CMS Analysis Facility at University of Nebraska, the CMS Analysis Facility at Purdue University, and the subMIT facility at MIT.

## Metric of Success

Facility metrics will be established as part of the benchmarking.

## Current Responsibilities for U.S. CMS

U.S. CMS is engaged in a number of research projects towards forward-looking analysis functionalities

## Gap Analysis, R&D Goals

The proposed R&D will target the definition of the larger AF software infrastructure. The goal is to finalize the development of data structures (column-wise data) for end-to-end physics data analyses, as well as assessing the effect on performance of data compression and caching, and of different job schedulers. Finally, as part of this work package, the need for beyond-batch capabilities will be addressed. This work package will utilize four R&D Analysis Facilities (AFs): the Elastic Analysis Facility (EAF) at Fermilab, the CMS Analysis Facility at University of Nebraska, the CMS Analysis Facility at Purdue University, and the subMIT facility at MIT.

## Metric of Success

Scale and functionality milestones, established via Challenges.

description.raw:
## Current Responsibilities for U.S. CMS

U.S. CMS is engaged in a number of research projects towards forward-looking analysis functionalities.

## Gap Analysis, R&D Goals

A common task in physics analysis on CMS is to derive additional synthesized data from available information, to create high-level cuts or in order to employ machine-learning (ML) based algorithms in their analysis design. Typically this is achieved by replicating an entire dataset with the added synthesized information, this usage pattern does not scale to petabyte-sized analysis datasets. A solution is to provide users with access to a data-store where they can write the synthesized data alone such that it can be joined with a common dataset (i.e. NanoAOD). At the same time, with the increasing popularity of ML applications for analysis, the development of capabilities to improve the training and to accelerate the inference of ML algorithms needs to be conducted.

## Metric of Success

Scale and functionality milestones, established via Challenges.

description.raw:
## Current Responsibilities for U.S. CMS

U.S. CMS participates in data challenges as an active partner of the WLCG.

## Gap Analysis, R&D Goals

To effectively integrate the products of development in the other work packages, system integration tests must be performed. Staged tests will demonstrate reliable performance of full systems at increased capacity, with the goal of reaching projected HL-LHC needs well in time for the start of data taking.

## Metric of Success

Appropriate throughput, volume, and latency metrics will be used to quantify the success of a given challenge.

description.raw:
## Current Responsibilities for U.S. CMS

The U.S. CMS S&C Operations Program R&D successfully operates several facilities: the  
Tier1 at Fermilab and the Tier 2 centers at 7 universities all with outstanding performance  
metrics. HPC centers have successfully been exploited for reconstruction, but they are all not  
yet fully integrated in the production cycle. The use of GPU accelerators is still in an R&D  
phase. Active networking is under development. A critical item in developing all aspects of  
these systems will be integrating them into a coherent and robust monitoring framework. The  
hooks needed for efficient monitoring should be designed into these systems from the  
beginning rather than retrofitted later.

## Gap Analysis, R&D Goals

The U.S. CMS S&C Operations Program R&D program has significant deliverables to the  
HL-HLC program as mentioned in the earlier work packages. Advancements in these areas, in  
particular for the movement of exabyte-scale datasets, networking, and analysis facilities, will  
require additional monitoring capabilities and training/documentation to ensure that new  
facilities and features are scalable and meet the needs of the operations staff. These monitoring  
enhancements will also need to include more granular information such as the efficient of use  
of accelarators/GPUs and HPC centers in a production setting or the transfer rates and  
locations of datasets in a datalake environment.

## Metric of Success

We are still developing the metrics for success. They will be different for each sub-project, but  
quality monitoring is the goal.

## Current Responsibilities for U.S. CMS

U.S. CMS has been instrumental in bringing new projects and infrastructure into production  
throughout the CMS era. The initial period where a new facility or tool goes into production typically results in many new feature requests and requires active user support.

## Gap Analysis, R&D Goals

The U.S. CMS S&C Operations Program R&D program has significant deliverables to the  
HL-HLC program as mentioned in the earlier work packages. Advancements in these areas, in  
particular for the movement of exabyte-scale datasets, networking, and analysis facilities, will  
require additional support to ensure that new facilities and features are scalable and meet the needs of the operations staff.

## Metric of Success

We are still developing the metrics for success. They will be different for each sub-project, but  
quality user support during the transition period is the goal.

description.raw:
## Current Responsibilities for U.S. CMS

U.S. CMS has been instrumental in bringing new projects and infrastructure into production  
throughout the CMS era. Deciding when a feature or a new initiative is ready for public  
consumption is an important part of the responsibility of the production team. Part of the  
readiness is based on whether or not documentation and training materials are written for users  
and operators.

## Gap Analysis, R&D Goals

This work package is really relates to how R&D products can be put  
into production. The availability of documentation is a key aspect of production-readiness.

## Metric of Success

Sufficient documentation is available for users and operations support team.
